62CF50E04790468DA59C33DAC8966B90.description: Examine the role of governmental and non-governmental organizations in studying the effects of human activities on one or more components of the hydrosphere.

0558968EC4804D28B9923D8D911E0894.description: Examine the impacts of climate change on the ability of oceans to moderate temperature, absorb carbon dioxide and resist acidification. (K, STSE)

FACCD0939EE145A48DF18AA561DFA2F0.description: Describe the ways in which changes in factors such as ocean salinity, ocean temperature and surface winds influence the processes of ocean convection and thermohaline circulation.

0BBC9982C3724EC58EB812538EE40E47.description: Correlate the locations of the large wind-driven surface ocean currents and thermohaline circulation on Earth.

0B5E56ABA6A0441483F7C787CFE70A5B.description: Explore how Earth’s oceans affect climate through heat storage and transfer.

8B9468E597774AF4844D9B63297F60B1.description: Consider how extended periods of glaciation, including potential Snowball Earth events, have impacted feedback loops related to the biosphere and other components of the geosphere

6F1E8F5D4E194921A52AF34DC590C729.description: Examine the importance of glaciers in the hydrologic cycle and Earth’s climate.

33CA94D9F77349C080E5BB7D0B31E35D.description: Provide examples of the ways in which rivers and streams erode, transport and deposit sediment to shape stream valleys and create depositional landforms such as deltas, levees and alluvial fans

2BD8860ED0D74FD6837267A59B987B9C.description: Examine how groundwater storage and flow, along with the depth of the water table, are key considerations affecting the location and maintenance of buildings and infrastructure, including drinking water supplies.

EAB632B9494C4299AF3C80BFE384939F.description: Provide examples of how groundwater works as an erosional agent, resulting in Karst topographic features such as sinkholes and caverns.

1FA76A049C3C43B6B491B98C6F2087BE.description: Model the movement of groundwater, including the locations of reservoirs and flows, in a hypothetical or actual groundwater system.

CA2A89FED2D94849BAAEE2CD4B2DFD53.description: Investigate how factors such as porosity and permeability influence the storage and movement of groundwater.

047C95DF5A5B4E5FB31C0532B6083B8A.description: Research the technologies (e.g., acoustics, imaging, buoys and underwater vehicles) and processes scientists use to learn about the hydrosphere.

90D7972CD19E4040BEC0B89594315D12.description: Discuss the types of evidence scientists gather to determine if water is or was present on other planets and celestial bodies

76088B5524084D1584B8DA8A1AAB14FB.description: Outline the distribution of the hydrosphere in groundwater, surface water, oceans, glaciers and the atmosphere.

08568A5371C64E87955404F047407926.description: Investigate the characteristics of the hydrosphere and how hydrospheric processes impact the atmosphere, biosphere and lithosphere.

43E7DFDE59F74B168FDA83473E5238EA.description: Relate terrestrial observations of storms to similar storms on the gas giant planets.

C6820A676C9844CFA8CBD300FDA1DA46.description: Recognize that methane measurements in Mars may provide evidence of anaerobic bacteria similar to those found on Earth.

CB04BEA66E254F8886C0EB11841FFAA7.description: Hypothesize what changes were present or would need to occur to other planet’s atmospheres in order to sustain life on those planets.

EA9268F1454A4D1D953B950BC01A20FA.description: Examine the effects of El Niño and La Niña on Saskatchewan and predict their effects on future seasons based on historical data.

E848C3AE6C1C4A7C96C796237123351A.description: Determine, using archived data, whether the frequency and severity of extreme weather events (e.g., tornadoes, hurricanes and blizzards) is changing locally, nationally and globally.

76319AB218C24553B9583F73181CF75F.description: Investigate the function and operation of various technologies (e.g., Earth orbiting satellites, drones, weather balloons, rocketsondes and radiosondes) used to gather data about the composition of the atmosphere.

D6322C18E18841D2AA7B950B7DF1B1A6.description: Describe the characteristics of notable climatic events (e.g., volcanic activity, Great Oxygenation Event, Snowball Earth events and asteroid collisions) in Earth’s history, the impacts of those events on the composition of the atmosphere and their correlation with the fossil and rock record.

B154B19AD7004676968E0D43084FE832.description: Explain how earth scientists use data such as ice composition, tree growth, sedimentary content and landforms to infer the composition of ancient climates.

EFCD9473650A4574A690318802584DA6.description: Investigate how factors such as the oxygen and carbon dioxide balance in the oceans influence the composition of Earth’s atmosphere.

CA302F3B778F47A0B0F068A2109E388B.description: Model the role of atmospheric layers in insulating Earth and protecting Earth’s surface from extra-terrestrial dangers such as ultraviolet light, solar wind and meteors.

5D1097FCFA88492DBC867256DA51AE71.description: Research the history of Earth’s atmosphere, including the origins and sources of nitrogen, oxygen and other gases (e.g., argon, carbon dioxide, neon, helium and methane) and the composition of those gases in today’s atmosphere.

07AC500FEE9049B1938B1827F4070F9F.description: Analyze the composition of Earth’s atmosphere and factors that influence changes in the composition in the short and long term.

F7A4E811A05442A8A58CC06A335F1BD3.description: Interpret and/or create a map of geological, civic and/or environmental data using a geographic information system (GIS) to correlate surface geography with human land use.

6DAD0C14CD344D09A8EF8E32358C7175.description: Investigate how data gathered by technologies such as Earth orbiting satellites and drones can document changes in land forms and help to identify potential surface geological hazards.

63A8D48BBBF74412A5F8A44C49472D9C.description: Apply mapping techniques such as creating and interpreting topographic profiles and translating between two-dimensional (2D) surface maps/crosssections and three-dimensional (3D) box diagrams to represent surface geographical features.

0F25690717B04764A0441508B4E7A762.description: Design, construct and test a model of a structure or process to withstand or mitigate short term (e.g., flooding, wind storm, tsunami, storm surge and earthquake) or long term (e.g., erosion and sinkholes) phenomena that affect surface geography.

597F319594894E23BD9FE0DF5A50EF02.description: Speculate on the possible involvement of erosional processes in the development of geographic features found on Mars and other celestial bodies.

C2B92434CFF244989DAE8D8591680F63.description: Explain how scientists use stratigraphic columns to infer sea level rise (transgression) and sea level fall (regression) over geologic time.

B9742F1FB99244078B869981BB082C51.description: Explain the importance of chemical weathering to soil quality and formation, atmospheric carbon dioxide and geochemical cycling.

1658F23105274761BDE7006DB84324F2.description: Describe the effects of mechanical weathering and erosion, including glaciation, on the surface geography of Saskatchewan as shown by landforms such as drumlins, moraines, eskers, kettles and outwash.

70F52AF3EBC548E783A767210BB0AF3A.description: Explain how surficial geological features of Saskatchewan such as the Athabasca Sand Dunes, Cypress Hills, Nipekamew Sand Cliffs and Qu’Appelle Valley are characterized by specific depositional and erosional processes.

1DDAD44FAD2744279D820A813F2288EC.description: Explain how specific landforms are a consequence of depositional and denudation processes (e.g., weathering, erosion, and mass wasting).

B2E9581E803D414093955F27AE5710BB.description: Observe, describe and locate common landforms (e.g., moraines, potholes, drumlins, buttes, coulees, dunes, oxbow lakes and river valleys) of Saskatchewan.

A1AACEDFC0994B8FA5C2CE876BE8BC48.description: Analyze surface geography as a product of deposition, weathering, erosion and mass wasting processes

C99B18E1143B4CF896C7AE425F421087.description: Research and investigate solutions to economic and environmental issues (e.g., managing mine tailings and pollutants, reclaiming open pit mining sites, ecological impact of pipelines, resource depletion and maintaining water quality) related to the extraction of geological resources in Saskatchewan.

5B586848CED34C248D50C34B2937280C.description: Explain the operation of various surface and sub-surface resource extraction technologies and processes and their associated environmental impacts for mining and resources such as oil sands, shale oil and potash.

AEBD295A80AD40538A1C49BCF8FF3FEC.description: Recognize the importance of water for various mining techniques such as solution mining and enhanced oil recovery.

C06CFE8E7CAE41FD9FB21DD9908F5A90.description: Examine the moral and legal obligations of governments and companies involved in resource development with respect to traditional lands and treaties with First Nations, Métis and indigenous people worldwide.

BFF6BB26B99340779D6308DFF84B096A.description: Discuss the engineering challenges (e.g., water incursion, sinkholes, Blairmore Formation for potash mining and ground support in hard rock mines), related to mining above and below ground in Saskatchewan.

B1E23195B21B4C7DA1111BE4DA522CCC.description: Recognize the importance of obtaining surface or core samples to examine the physical characteristics and geochemistry of potential ore bodies and natural resource deposits.

7FA1E41743614DE6BB5B73B49674D1D1.description: Model a seismic survey using tools such as an ultrasonic motion detector.

B96F15EAE14F4756B4435460507F986F.description: Explain how geologists use applications of seismic body waves (i.e., longitudinal p-wave and transverse s-wave), surface waves and the laws of reflection and refraction to determine the presence and position of economically useful geological deposits.

8F74E8DC3F9743E4B0E9D0CD4BC301C3.description: Identify anomalies from geophysical surveys and geologic maps and relate them to structural features and associated resource deposits.

922381903600452D81C2024529EC8F77.description: Contrast the operation and utility of different imaging methods (e.g., satellite imaging, gravity, magnetics, electromagnetics and seismic) used to locate hard rock and soft rock resource deposits.

A8338D9133A94EE69BF02AAC38D661A0.description: Investigate how depositional setting and geologic history influences the location of major mineral and fossil fuel resources in Saskatchewan

15DDAF8A2FC04A48994FD97E99F1D3FF.description: Identify the surface and sub-surface geologic features associated with major mineral (e.g., gold, diamond, rare earth elements, copper, zinc, kaolin, potash, uranium, sodium sulfate and salt), building stone, aggregate and fossil fuel resources of Saskatchewan.

0F25D4C668BD41429BE9AF6F7A99D442.description: Identify the location, method of extraction, uses and economic impact of major fossil fuel and mineral (e.g., gold, diamond, rare earth elements, copper, zinc, kaolin, coal, potash, uranium, sodium sulfate and salt) resources locally, provincially and/or globally.

727151340E3C484F82BED526E5AAF137.description: Investigate the processes and technologies used to locate and extract mineral resources and fossil fuels locally, provincially and globally.

D525967A231942828F5E42BACD94D886.description: Research the ways in which society makes use of sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic rocks for various purposes such as art, architecture, industrial materials and energy resources including petroleum, natural gas, potash and uranium.

93A6CA804E8446AC8280A89B0C2955CE.description: Create, and validate with the help of others, a resource such as a field guide for a specific mineral or rock group.

A42A187649284E62860D85A1C4FA468A.description: Correlate the location and composition of depositional layers to major events such as volcanic eruptions, glaciation, flooding, mountain building and metamorphism.

BA2866D42F5549BB8924FCF5D577FF4A.description: Explain why locations where igneous activity and metamorphic rocks occur correlate with plate boundaries and plate movement.

DD439A8C08064049A626EC3542456E5A.description: Compare the characteristics of foliated and non-foliated metamorphic rocks.

48FC467FD8154C948BAC9983C1CB195A.description: Describe how the agents of metamorphism (i.e., heat, pressure, directional stress and chemically active fluids) influence the formation of metamorphic rocks.

1D960CFA46504DBAB6D6EEC7432D4289.description: Compare the major features of continental, marine and transitional depositional (sedimentary) environments through structures such as grain size, bedding, ripple marks, mud cracks and fossils in various sedimentary rock formations

53C288CA68F34604911B8FB6DC1A8DD8.description: Describe how the general mechanisms of mechanical and chemical weathering processes, erosion and deposition contribute to the development of sedimentary rocks.

A5EAC8BFF29843A9877D39DAC2E59247.description: Explain how geologists can infer how an igneous rock was formed by examining its texture (i.e., intrusive or extrusive).

271AE3A9649F43508183F6831BC46C82.description: Classify igneous rocks according to criteria such as method of formation (i.e., intrusive or extrusive) and mineral composition (e.g., felsic or mafic).

8C5C44D0AF7545AFA258027AAD5B2173.description: Outline the basic transitions inherent in the rock cycle, and the forces that disrupt equilibrium to cause these transitions.

FC3693E6E71A4A2CA18186E1767E83BD.description: Differentiate among the three main rock groups (i.e., igneous, sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic) by their processes of formation, including the roles of time, heat and pressure.

C9BE4450B4524122A43606EB23533710.description: Observe and classify mineral samples using standard physical properties (e.g., cleavage, fracture, crystal form, hardness, lustre, colour, magnetism and streak).

2C815893486A4C9C9200A52C027B3709.description: Compare the three primary methods of mineral formation (i.e., precipitation of mineral matter, crystallization of molten rock and deposition resulting from biological processes).

F64CFCE4BAD640E896F8620C2F79907D.description: Identify the characteristics geologists use to determine whether an Earth material is a mineral.

CE28C00BE3574795BE7C928EC27FA012.description: Pose scientific questions about the characteristics and formation of rocks and minerals

D259DAAB95A24E46A82653979868FAEC.description: Examine the processes that lead to the formation of sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic rocks and minerals.

9F9724A150134A0A9E662073C6B8B425.description: Provide examples that show geologists can learn about Earth’s formation and early history by studying other objects in the solar system

E337D1E4449144569E8FE9889FFAC0EC.description: Discuss how scientists revise the geologic time scale in response to new geological and fossil evidence.

5176B266BB0E4BEBA25E3AE0C6A0F828.description: Contrast absolute and relative dating principles and techniques and the benefits of each.

F863C0DA37934AE7A27B6A70E17858AE.description: Describe how and why scientists use radiometric dating techniques to determine the absolute age of rocks

BA74F42C620A46BBBC02DCF3F5EA8A29.description: Provide examples of the key concepts of relative dating, including the law of superposition, principle of uniformitarianism, principle of original horizontality, principle of cross-cutting relationships, principle of inclusions and components, principle of faunal succession, principle of lateral continuity, and unconformities.

60C5D5C0906E4592BE8BA5A7618594FE.description: Contrast absolute and relative dating principles and techniques and the benefits of each.

59562BB8EB4D4EE89554B639793C1A8D.description: Research the consequences of catastrophic events such as asteroid impacts (at Cretaceous-Tertiary [K-T] boundary in Saskatchewan), glaciation and volcanism on the fossil record.

2AA4AF6389A94136B2AD728A6A40173E.description: Outline the major geological and biological events that occurred during a particular eon, era, period or epoch of the geologic time scale.

BF1E405137B241D29EC227BC80A4644E.description: Recognize that the nomenclature (e.g., eon, era, period and epoch) and major divisions of the geologic time scale are based on scientists’ interpretation of the fossil record.

FEBD8257406C4349BAB1DDED7F326F39.description: Assess the importance of the fossil record as evidence to support scientific understanding of geological time and evolution.

5482D0C2ED56401A984017A582A58708.description: Analyze how geologists use the fossil record and relative and absolute dating methods to determine the geological history of Earth and to construct the geologic time scale.

74DBDD8664E845BCA6AC3EAEE8F76FE4.description: Consider which celestial bodies (e.g., Mars, Europa and exoplanets) could have or could not have geological features that might be explained by plate tectonics.

BA2DB5F3B3134EBBA8352648C57027AB.description: Predict the locations of future plate boundaries based on current lithospheric plate movement rates and compare with scientific predictions.

12A87F0E9F4D41EBAEB3A6492278260D.description: Analyze data, using tools such as satellite photos and the Global Positioning System (GPS), to determine the rate of relative lithospheric plate motion.

502D18D3D8C9472896AE057FD0FCFB31.description: Model the movement of lithospheric plates over geologic time and relate this to the geologic history of Saskatchewan.

B8217CC8CA5B4262BC74C7D2310CA44F.description: Correlate the world distribution of mountain ranges, volcanoes and earthquakes with the location, boundaries and movement of lithospheric plates.

6AC772EAB9A44FAB834E1B46C9D94B24.description: Describe the formation of geological features (e.g., ocean trenches, midocean ridges, transform faults, mountain ranges and island arcs) associated with convergent, divergent and transform boundaries, with reference to the asthenosphere, lithosphere and mantle convection

F03A87BE949F447486698594CC713E02.description: Discuss the scientific belief that the movement of tectonic plates was responsible for the formation and break up of continents (e.g., Pangea, Rodinia and Gondwana) over geological time.

D0A95FC27F0748B8AF3BBD468C208749.description: Research the development of the continental drift hypothesis, including the evidence (e.g., fossil, mineral, ancient climates and continental shape) scientists used to support this hypothesis.

61882C0C114A4994A47DCB7632AC5155.description: Explain the key principles and driving forces of plate tectonics theory including how the theory subsumes ideas related to continental drift.

D661287A137B48E7AD9EFF20473FAC1E.description: Discuss the importance of plate tectonics as the unifying concept in earth science.

8DA6D1DAFD6444308F9D511D7F41E268.description: Examine the evidence for and the importance of plate tectonics theory in explaining the processes that produced Earth’s major surface features.

BEC87F02E18E4244AE3AE02F9B930380.description: Identify the significance of contributions made by Canadians to the field of earth science.

A016224B0DC94E9787276B33A747FA16.description: Assess how earth science processes and principles are applicable to the study of other planets and celestial bodies

DB531D6749E84F319D3B9665E1D6EC19.description: Recognize how historical and contemporary observations, including those made by First Nations and Métis peoples, can contribute to a greater understanding of Earth’s processes.

5B5BBB90E5614953A4124EDCC042402C.description: Identify issues and events in Saskatchewan that might be studied from an earth science perspective.

3605A9E0A3304F248422CF43034A1F54.description: Identify how earth scientists draw upon principles and processes from scientific fields such as biology, chemistry, computer science, geology, mathematics, and physics in order to address their questions

852E9ADD5D55447CBED8BFDC0540EC8B.description: Provide examples of how earth scientists collect evidence using analytical, field, theoretical, experimental and/or modeling studies

3370917553374C5482441236B8B54DE8.description: Examine why earth scientists utilize a systems approach by considering boundaries, inputs, outputs and feedback loops when investigating an earth science issue.

F9D7C6C398DA4274887EBFEBA49578AC.description: Outline possible interactions between two or more of Earth’s spheres within the context of a particular event and/or issue.

3BCAB2C6DB5E4095A852FE80B1F33BE0.description: Discuss why earth scientists consider interactions between and within two or more of Earth’s spheres when they study earth processes.

AFE16EA9515F4695ABDF3B62AD22F542.description: Differentiate between the characteristics of the four major Earth spheres (i.e., atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and lithosphere).

7652CD2C117A4B0889CC711185271B47.description: Construct a representation of the major fields of earth science and the major topics of study within each field.

62C459E23D03411C87E8277528CD6E8A.description: Examine the multi-disciplinary nature of earth science.

6A2C6EF7988C41838D33E6E888BD8CCB.description: Produce a profile of the earth beneath their feet by locating oneself on the geological profile of Saskatchewan and relating this to the geological history of your area.

66EDCBFE729E47CAA8FD5F7ECA443775.description: Consider natural disasters in the news and discuss causes of these phenomena and their impacts on the human environment and natural environment.

2204244EFE454A079AB070B8E8E6E986.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peerevaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a studentdirected study

C4F4E9C7A73749AFB3CAE800714F9167.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, song, game, commercial, fine art representation, video or research paper.

34F56BF186BC4F229F6823BD391B4535.description: Debate an issued related to earth science, including developing materials to support the arguments for and arguments against a position.

37148589861C4581B8BC6F24D5648210.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying concept related to an Earth Science 30 topic.

3E1646EEFC0940F69655514AF43907C3.description: Participate in and reflect on a field experience related to one or more topics of Earth Science 30.

9E0CB1189DA144E194E412C606B4AF0D.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a topic of interest related to biology.

7CC5C63B25674729BC37DE1F8A2A9EEF.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Earth Science 30

B25ABED1DDF34DC49923B759D86F0EB0.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Earth Science 30 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data

E17730D629CD417E89AF0F59D4756F90.description: Use acquired knowledge to develop a plan to attain a job of personal interest in the earth science field.

B680F9918016478F8027A657807CA217.description: Communicate research findings related to earth science occupations through a display, brochure, video, presentation software, website or orally.

A3814B91E639416A8631C53369376E31.description: Participate in, and reflect on, an earth-science related field experience.

4974D0D70BB840CC8D5085D6D9993DC4.description: Examine the role of regulatory (e.g., Association of Professional Engineers and Geoscientists of Saskatchewan [APEGS]) and non-regulatory (e.g., Saskatchewan Geological Survey, Saskatchewan Mining Association, Canadian Geophysical Union and the Canadian Water Resources Association) bodies that support earth scientists.

E0EB4774D47841758DD99D46B219B871.description: Compare the roles and responsibilities of various earth science professionals as they engage with a specific project.

E48D902F5A0B4F21B08EA08CB48B0D12.description: Reflect upon personal suitability or non-suitability for a specific earthscience related occupation considering criteria such as: i. initial and continuing educational requirements; ii. duties and skills required for this occupation; iii. the work environment, including typical hours and shifts worked and typical locations; iv. current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to the rest of Canada; v. physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; vi. workplace hazards and safety considerations; vii. other occupations with which they interact; viii. professional and/or licensing requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and ix. future trends impacting the occupation.

564420D117A4448492AEBB34717C1D36.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common to people involved in earth-science related jobs.

54C95949243742AF8394903C562DE724.description: Identify which earth-science related occupations are facing shortages and which are oversubscribed locally, regionally and/or nationally

078346F185814634BAF7EB6CEF783C81.description: Explore the connection between topics in Earth Science 30 and occupations of personal interest.

7476517C465C495B99E85ADC3B57D152.description: Generate a list of occupations that require a background in earth science through research and/or participation in events such as a career fair or job shadow.

89E7807DD81848F49AB19D0A078356DD.description: Analyze and explore earth-science related career paths in Saskatchewan, Canada and the world.
